The research was prompted by a Mumsnet survey indicating some parents provided packed lunches due to perceived pickiness. Trust chairman Rob Rees highlighted the role of school meals in encouraging children to try new foods, while Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton noted the positive peer influence at school. School meals in England must adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary school children and slightly fewer in secondary schools eating them. In contrast, about 46% of children in Scotland eat school lunches. The survey was conducted online from 26 February to 5 March among parents with children aged 4-17.

Alvaro Morata, 23, is playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, with a buy-back option for Real valued at up to 30 million euros. Morata, once a target for Arsenal and Chelsea, has scored three goals for Spain in the tournament. During his time at Juventus, he scored 27 goals over two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He participated in consecutive Champions League finals, coming on as a substitute in Real's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. Morata, a 6ft 3in striker, debuted for Real Madrid's first team at 18 and scored 10 goals for them in La Liga.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but has been without a team since being released in May. During his second spell at Forest, he made 51 appearances. Before joining Celtic, he spent four seasons at Forest and also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

The passage describes Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, planning to exit its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to a new business under a deal with Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company led by billionaire Ron Burkle. Tesco will loan the new business around £80 million as part of the exit strategy. Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its 2007 opening. The deal involves closing 50 stores, with the remaining 150 transferring to Yucaipa. Tesco will incur a £150 million cost to dispose of the brand, part of which is a loan that may be repaid. If Yucaipa turns the business profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. This move follows Tesco's first annual profit decline in 20 years, reported in April.

The passage describes an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it, as explained to BBC Sport's Nick Hope. After briefly considering representing France, the individual is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, there is a mention of a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

The passage discusses the significant reduction in glacier coverage in the French Alps from the late 1960s/early 1970s to the late 2000s, with the area decreasing from about 375 sq km to 275 sq km, representing a 26% loss over 40 years. This research, presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues, who produced a new inventory of the French Alps glaciers, assessing around 600 glaciers across several massifs, including Mont Blanc. The study utilized map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to verify automatic delineation due to issues like debris cover and deep shadows. The findings indicate that glacial retreat is more pronounced in the southern Alps, with the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs experiencing significant losses, compared to the northern Alps, where conditions such as higher precipitation and cloud cover contribute to slower retreat. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has seen a slight reduction in area. The research aligns with broader observations of glacial retreat in the Alps, with similar trends reported by Swiss researchers.

The passage describes Scotland's strong performance in their World Cup qualifiers, having won all five matches so far. They are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a victory likely securing their place in the finals. Scotland's forward, Evans, emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals, having experienced play-off losses in the past. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for determining the group leader. Scotland is in a favorable position to qualify automatically for the finals in the Netherlands, as the top six group runners-up will also qualify. Evans highlights the significance of fan support and the diverse experience of the squad, with many players competing in top leagues abroad. She reflects on her success with Bayern Munich and the benefits of playing in competitive leagues for the national team's development.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London, who alleged harassment over a two-year period. The harassment reportedly involved tweets, which Campbell insists were not threatening. He criticized the media for creating "innuendo" to fuel speculation. Campbell, a Scottish independence advocate and founder of the Wings Over Scotland blog, was released on bail pending further inquiries, with a court date set for mid-September. He stated that the tweets in question are still publicly visible and not threatening. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating the online harassment allegation. Campbell mentioned on Twitter that he would post less frequently due to reasons beyond his control.

The passage discusses a proposal by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) to replace the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a modern, animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of animal cruelty, while the mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, believes the mascot is beloved and does not represent cruelty. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway, has become synonymous with the resort. Macey states that while PETA's suggestion will be considered by the council, he does not anticipate much support for changing the mascot, as it is seen as a positive symbol for Skegness.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Georgia initially scored through Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson extended Scotland's lead after the break, followed by another try from Lobzhanidze and a counter-attack finish by Hogg. Scotland dominated possession, scoring five tries and converting them with Greig Laidlaw, leading to a 38-11 score by early in the second half. Georgia managed to score two tries, one from Lobzhanidze, but struggled with their scrum, leading to penalties and a yellow card for Moray Low. Scotland's substitutes, Ali Price and Rory Hughes, contributed to the final score. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's first-half performance and pragmatic approach in the second half, despite challenging conditions. The match highlighted Scotland's strong possession and counter-attacking play, while Georgia's scrum issues were a significant factor in their defeat.

In the match, Widnes led 14-6 at half-time due to tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Paddy Flynn scoring for Castleford. Flynn added another try early in the second half, but Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor extended Widnes' lead to 38-12. Despite three quick tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn, Widnes held on to win. Mellor's try after a Castleford short kick-off gave Widnes a 26-point lead. Castleford's defense faltered, allowing Patrick, who recently signed a three-year deal from Huddersfield, to score. Gale and Flynn, on loan from Widnes, made the finish tense, but Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat. Widnes moved into seventh place, above Wakefield, while Castleford remained sixth, one point above the Vikings. The match featured players from both teams, with referees led by J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat." Detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies, he had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. His release was facilitated by the Periodic Review Board's July decision. Al-Odah, who claims he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid, boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and expressed no bitterness, only excitement and joy. He will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait, as per the release terms. His release, the first since May's exchange of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, reduces the Guantanamo inmate count to 148. The facility, opened in January 2002 post-9/11, is slated for closure by President Barack Obama.

The passage describes the commemoration of Anzac Day, which honors the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One at Gallipoli. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, and up to 400 people participated in a parade before laying a wreath at the Cenotaph. An additional service was held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. Anzac Day was first commemorated in the capital in 1916 when King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey. The event is significant for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen in all wars. Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, spoke at the dawn service, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the courage of the Anzac troops. The parade at the Cenotaph included veterans' associations, service personnel, and their families, with crowds of Australia and New Zealand expats watching. The ceremony featured prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The Gallipoli campaign, lasting eight months, was one of the bloodiest of the war, aiming to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, aged 30, rejoined Premiership Well for a second spell in July and is poised to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa. He previously scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has mostly played as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has been maintaining his fitness through games with the U20s, expressed readiness and eagerness to start. He has been capped twice for Scotland in 2008 and has nearly 400 senior club appearances, having played for teams like Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, are seven points ahead of Alloa. Clarkson emphasized the importance of winning games to build confidence and push the club up the table.

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were concerns that the new ownership might not maintain the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that productive talks led to guarantees that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and its members now have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan's private office confirmed that the current pension arrangements would continue under the new ownership. Steve Harley met with Boparan representatives at Bernard Matthews' headquarters, where it was emphasized that the new owner aims to restore the company's profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The passage describes a scrutiny meeting of the council addressing issues with a new ferry service. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July due to ongoing problems, and a review of the project by auditors was ordered. Since its launch on May 14, the ferry has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues, with cars also being damaged during boarding. Local business owner Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation for local businesses is under discussion, noting that the ferry is a prototype with expected teething problems. He stated that electrical issues have been fixed, ramp extensions are being made to prevent vehicle damage, and seamanship issues causing groundings have been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that fishing regions in the UK, which largely supported leaving the EU, are concerned about being marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), criticized for its impact on British fishing, was a factor in the industry's support for Brexit, with hopes of regaining control over UK waters and becoming a leading fish-exporting nation like Norway.

However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the fishing industry, contributing only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people, might be a low priority but should not be marginalized. The report notes that the UK shares commercial fish stocks with other EU states and relies on the EU for fish exports, while importing a significant portion of its fish. Continued market access may require trade-offs, such as allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters in exchange for zero-tariff access to the EU market.

The report suggests retaining elements of the CFP post-Brexit, including quotas based on scientific advice and cooperation with neighboring states. It also raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland if the UK leaves the EU.

Despite these challenges,

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or allowing images to be taken from April 2004 to February 2014, involving young boys in erotic poses. He was placed on the sex offenders register and given a community payback order. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching register due to his conduct being incompatible with teaching standards. The court heard that his actions supported an industry that abuses children, and his behavior was not isolated but part of a pattern over many years. The panel concluded there was a strong likelihood of recurrence of his behavior, leading to his removal from the register and a two-year prohibition from reapplying. Geaney, 69 at sentencing, was not present at the hearing.

The passage describes a fire incident on 2 March at a site in Duncan Street, which led to reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire. Although the fire service noted the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the past year. Concerns were raised by the fire service to the EA about the potential impact of a fire on residents, transport, and the environment. This led to joint visits by fire safety officers and EA staff, resulting in enforcement action against the site operators, Asset and Land Group. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed, preventing the company from operating at the site and requiring waste removal. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses Syria's efforts and challenges in complying with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire chemical stockpile. He mentioned that a shipment was attacked twice by "terrorist groups" en route to the port of Latakia. Al-Mekdad criticized US condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, asserting that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks and accusing the US of supporting terrorists. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported significant civilian casualties in Aleppo due to barrel bombs, while the Aleppo Media Centre claimed rebels had seized control of Aleppo's central prison, a claim denied by Syrian state media. The US has expressed concern over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan, with only 4% of the chemical stockpile removed. Russia has urged Syria to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by March 1, with a deadline for destruction by the end of June. The OPCW acknowledged that security concerns have slowed the destruction process, but Syria remains committed to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The passage describes England's significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, which leveled the series with a day to spare. England set a formidable target by scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, marking their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. Root's promotion to number three was praised by captain Alastair Cook, who also scored 105 and 76 not out. England's coach, Trevor Bayliss, commended Root's hard work and improvement following a previous defeat. The passage notes Pakistan's struggles, batting for only 63 and 70 overs in their two innings, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq scoring over 50 runs. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott predicted England's continued success, while Vaughan suggested the series would remain competitive. Misbah expressed disappointment and a need for improved confidence and shot selection.

The passage describes the efforts of Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, to gather experiences from pensioners and their families regarding residential care. This evidence will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of her review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and their caregivers, highlighting both positive and negative care experiences. She aims to address unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales by examining factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Her team will also engage with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The review seeks to ensure that those responsible for residential care understand the realities of living in such settings and the necessary actions to improve quality of life. However, Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, expresses disappointment that no care home expert is on the advisory panel, missing an opportunity for partnership and full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder, has been the player-manager of Arbroath since 2010 and has now been appointed as the manager of Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing last in League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, mentioned that Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after a thorough process. Although Arbroath chairman John Christison wished to keep Sheerin, he understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and he earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. He transitioned into coaching and led Arbroath to win the Scottish Third Division title and achieve promotion in 2011, marking their first national trophy.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea is seeking a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the preferred candidate. The club is aware of the challenges in avoiding relegation, noting the strength of the Championship and the difficulty of immediate promotion, as seen with Norwich, Burnley, and Newcastle. Curtis, a former player, reflects on Swansea's decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, attributing it to frequent managerial changes and a loss of the club's identity, known as the "Swansea Way." Despite these challenges, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League. He emphasizes the club's history and significance to new signings, particularly through the documentary "Jack to a King," to instill a sense of responsibility and awareness of the club's journey from near bankruptcy to Premier League status.

The passage describes Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, who played a pivotal role in mapping the human genome, turning it into a competitive race. Despite criticism from the scientific community for his approach and lack of modesty, his work significantly accelerated genomic research. After mapping the human genome, Venter focused on creating synthetic life forms, leading to the development of Synthia, published in the journal Science. His early life included a stint as a naval orderly in Vietnam, which inspired his sense of urgency and determination to become a doctor. Venter excelled in research during his medical training and made significant contributions to molecular biology by focusing on RNA to speed up gene sequencing. His departure from the NIH in 1992 led to the founding of The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, which aimed to decode the human genome in three years. Despite facing criticism for his methods, Venter's financial success allowed him to pursue independent research. In 2006, he established the J Craig Venter Institute to create synthetic life forms. Additionally, he conducted oceanic expeditions to sequence microbial genomes, aiming to advance understanding of gene evolution and function. Venter envisions synthetic microbes as a potential catalyst for a new industrial revolution, offering environmental benefits.

The passage discusses the quality and structure of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries, particularly Germany. The Sutton Trust warns that many English apprenticeships are low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 starting each year rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. In contrast, Germany offers more apprenticeships, with 570,000 for young people, 90% of which are at A-level equivalence. The report highlights that only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. It notes that England's vocational system is fragmented, with 18,000 different qualifications, unlike Germany's 330. Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships in England have been below level three, and 75% are for those over 25. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, aiming for 300,000 new starts annually, with most at level three or higher. It emphasizes the need for high-quality vocational courses and improved career guidance. The Department for Education states that apprenticeships are being reformed to meet employer needs, with over a million people becoming apprentices since 2010. The Association of Colleges acknowledges the challenge of creating more apprenticeships but

The passage describes the achievements of the British Paralympian, Storey, who recently won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, aged 37, is aiming for further success at the upcoming Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 golds, eight silvers, and three bronzes across six Paralympics in cycling and swimming. Storey has won 21 world titles in both sports and is set to win her 17th title in the upcoming road race. She began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Hereford United, known as the Bulls, faced financial difficulties that led to their expulsion from the Football Conference. Despite a dramatic final-day escape that kept them in the Conference Premier, they failed to meet the Conference's payment deadlines to their creditors, totaling £148,000. The Conference extended the deadline multiple times, but Hereford, under new owner Tommy Agombar, did not meet the final deadline, resulting in their expulsion on June 10. Chester City, previously expelled in 2010, was reinstated in their place. Hereford's financial woes were compounded by debts of approximately £225,000, including £70,000 owed to HMRC. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust offered to buy the club for £1, but this was not the preferred option for the club's chairman, who was in talks with other bidders. The club's financial decline was worsened by reduced attendance, with the average gate dropping from 3,270 in League Two to 1,758 in the Conference Premier.

The passage provides information about a former Manchester City player who, at 30 years old, earned 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. The player holds the record for the most caps for the England Under-21 team, with 46 caps starting from 2004. He scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The player expressed a wish for success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters, indicating a decision based on common sense.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood was renowned for his work with leading orchestras worldwide and founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for about 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, recognized by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held early positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. Hogwood served as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and was a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor at the University of Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell University. He was celebrated for his generosity and influence in historically informed music, with many leading musicians having started their careers with him. His legacy continues to inspire, as noted by Richard Egarr, the AAM's music director,

The passage describes the situation of a boy from Northern Ireland whose family wishes to remain anonymous. His mother had to leave her job to care for him, and in June, his parents decided to remove him from mainstream school due to his difficulties. They applied for a place at a special school but are still waiting, as all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full. The boy's mother expressed her concerns on the BBC's Good Morning Ulster programme, highlighting her son's isolation and the challenges faced by families in similar situations. Recently, the family was informed that an extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, and they hope their son can start attending soon. However, the mother worries about the capacity issues in the special needs school system. The Education Authority responded by stating they cannot comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns but are reviewing the need for special school places to ensure availability close to where children live, with plans to assist placements from 2016.

The passage discusses a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) for Newport Gwent Dragons, with a shareholder vote scheduled for 9 May. The WRU intends to use Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue, which conflicts with the Football League's rules against artificial surfaces. Newport County, who have a lease until 2023, and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two, with a chance to secure survival. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey and County chairman Foxall emphasize the importance of honoring existing contracts. Foxall warns that relegation from the Football League would be a significant blow to Newport.

The passage describes the experiences of an individual who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during Sierra Leone's civil war, which ended in 2002. At 15, he was forced into the jungle, trained to use a gun, and subjected to brutal acts, including threats of mutilation and witnessing cannibalism. He escaped to Freetown, where he lived alone and engaged in petty crime before being imprisoned. In jail, he met a preacher, Richard Cole, who inspired him to rebuild his life and contribute positively to society. 

During the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone in 2014, he and others, despite not being medical practitioners, developed a clinic to treat Ebola cases. They focused on education, community support, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit, saving many lives. The individual now regrets his past actions and is committed to investing in young people to build a better future. The passage also provides statistics on Ebola deaths in West Africa and other countries.

The passage describes a situation where approximately 80,000 items, including art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, were at risk of being auctioned to settle a pension debt of the pottery firm Waterford Wedgwood plc. A public fundraising campaign, initiated in September, successfully reached its goal within a month, preventing the sale. The collection will remain on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The campaign was led by the Art Fund, and administrator Bob Young expressed satisfaction with the outcome, attributing it to the goodwill and determination shown during negotiations. The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension debt after the firm's collapse in 2009, and a high court judge had previously ruled that the collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. Alison Wedgwood emphasized the collection's importance to Staffordshire, noting it would have been dispersed globally without the fundraising. Tristram Hunt MP highlighted the collection's significance to Britain's cultural history and national identity.

The passage discusses a potential deal involving Wright, who may buy 20% of Billericay, with finer details yet to be released. The Sun reports that Wright will become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, known for being the runner-up in "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, has played non-league football for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 weekly in the club. Additionally, the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute when Nathan Delfouneso's chip was turned in by Jamille Matt. Colchester equalized shortly after, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from a corner. Blackpool had several chances to win, including a missed header by Tom Aldred from a corner 15 minutes from time. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister. Key moments included saves by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe and a late red card for Colchester. The match was reported by the Press Association.

The passage describes plans to transform the disused Fawley power station chimney into the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, as part of a £1 billion "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside developers. The power station, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years, is located on the western side of Southampton Water and was commissioned in 1971. The development will feature a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 300-acre site was acquired by the developers in 2016. The chimney, a 198-meter-high structure, is considered a signature piece and is central to the development plans. Outline planning permission is expected later this year, with construction potentially starting in 2018. The power station, a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired facility, was capable of powering one million homes and was fueled by the nearby Esso refinery.

The passage describes the performances of British cyclists at the Hong Kong championships. Lachlan Latham, aged 23, won a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham overtook Polish rider Adrian Teklinski (gold) and German Lucass Liss (silver) in the final sprint. In the men's team pursuit, Britain finished behind Italy for the bronze medal. Joe Truman, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, was eliminated in his semi-final. The women's team pursuit team, including Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker, finished fifth in the heats and did not qualify for the bronze-medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman praised Latham's strategic race and final sprint. Six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy noted the unpredictability of the event and commended Latham's sensible riding. Elinor Barker, part of the women's team pursuit squad, expressed optimism about the team's future despite not medaling. Double Olympic gold medallist Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighted the potential of the young team. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint,

The passage discusses Ross Kemp's return to the TV show "EastEnders" as Grant Mitchell for Barbara's final episodes. Kemp, who last played the role in 2006, described his return as brief but necessary, as he could not refuse the opportunity to be part of Barbara's storyline. Barbara, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, made a surprise return to the show in 2010 and announced her character would be killed off due to cancer. The producers revealed that Peggy, Barbara's character, would die from the disease in upcoming episodes. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, will reunite the Mitchell family for these final scenes. The storyline aims to bring the Mitchell brothers together for the last time with their mother. Grant Mitchell is noted as a memorable character in the show's history, known for his involvement in family dramas. The executive producer, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, highlighted the significance of the Mitchell brothers' reunion and the opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden's performances.

The passage discusses Tottenham Hotspur's disappointing performance at Anfield against Liverpool, where Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession. Mauricio Pochettino, Tottenham's manager, criticized the team's lack of desire and readiness to compete for the Premier League title, especially after a poor start to the game. He highlighted the challenge of fighting for the title if Chelsea extends their lead to 12 points. Tottenham has struggled in away games, winning only twice since September 24, with a poor record against top-six teams. Former player Danny Murphy noted the team's defensive issues and suggested sticking to a back three formation against stronger opponents. He also pointed out the contrast between Tottenham's home and away performances, emphasizing the need for improvement.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) achieved a significant victory in Nigeria's recent elections, winning 19 out of 28 governorships, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's success continued from the presidential election, where Muhammadu Buhari defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, and he will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP's decline was evident as it lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, but retained Rivers State. The PDP won eight governorships, mainly in the south-east, while Taraba's results are pending, and Imo's election was inconclusive. Elections were not held in seven states.

The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with strongholds in the south-east and Niger Delta, but it failed to win any of the five oil-producing states, posing a challenge for Buhari regarding potential disruptions to oil revenue. The elections, though marred by violence in some areas, were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP, which governed for 16 years, faces a need for introspection and rebuilding under

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, known as HebCelt, is taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. This year's lineup includes acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival is introducing an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews from signs and posters on-site using their phones and tablets. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan highlights that this feature enhances the festival experience and enables global interaction, allowing people to engage with the festival and its atmosphere from anywhere. The app will provide updates on information, interviews, and ticket purchases throughout the event.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, due to concerns about their management. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, face potential funding loss unless issues are addressed. A head teacher from one of the Trojan Horse schools reported parental interference and pressure during an Ofsted inspection, feeling isolated until the Trojan Horse letter was revealed. Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted for a hardline Muslim takeover, with five schools, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. The Department for Education, through Lord Nash, criticized Park View for failing to promote holistic pupil development and expressed concerns about discrimination and equality. Park View and Nansen Primary's funding agreements are set to be terminated, with the trust invited to respond by 4 July. Oldknow Academy Trust must address specific issues, such as ending discrimination and ensuring a balanced curriculum, by the same deadline. Ofsted's report on Park View highlighted inadequate safety measures and unvetted external speakers. Parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, claiming bias, and have invited Education Secretary Michael Gove for an open meeting to discuss the findings.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court argued that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal." Ms. Rose, who denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter, allegedly failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and did not refer him for further investigation. This oversight led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution claims that Vinnie's death was preventable had Ms. Rose performed her duties properly, emphasizing that her conduct was criminally negligent given the risk of death. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he met through an adult website, which he filmed. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day and was convicted of causing her and her father to view sexual images, as well as behaving abusively. Weatherhogg, from Guthrie near Forfar, was placed on the sex offenders register and remanded to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. The woman testified she felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. Despite being a first offender and assessed as posing a "moderate risk" of re-offending, Lady Wolffe emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's abhorrence of his actions. Weatherhogg's defense counsel described his remand as a "dramatic shock."

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson scoring 56, Gary Wilson contributing 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield adding 39 runs. Despite their efforts, Afghanistan won by chasing down 166 with 4 wickets in hand, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Afghanistan's opening stand of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai was crucial, and Amir Hamza was the standout bowler with 2-23. Ireland's opener Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck, and they faced a setback with paceman Boyd Rankin's absence due to a back problem. Rankin is expected to return for the upcoming five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on March 15. Ireland and Afghanistan will meet again in a second T20 at the same venue on Friday. Porterfield noted that Ireland could have scored more and fell short with their bowling execution.

The passage discusses Barcelona's handling of the Neymar transfer amid allegations of financial irregularities. Barcelona insists they have not committed any offense, stating their aim was to cover potential interpretations of Neymar's contract. The club paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m. Including various fees and a recent tax payment, Neymar's total cost to the club is £106.8m. Sandro Rosell, the former Barcelona president, resigned amid accusations of misappropriation and is under investigation, which he denies. A Spanish judge ruled there was enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax-related crime, claiming their tax declaration of €13.55m was to protect the club's reputation, despite believing their original tax payment was correct. It remains unclear if the case will be dropped following this payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

The passage describes the investigation into the murders of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, whose bodies were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. Metropolitan Police officers from the UK collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery. The UK detectives have completed their review in Thailand and will return to compile a report and update the families. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA verification and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. Thai police claim DNA from the suspects matches samples found on Ms. Witheridge. Post-mortem examinations revealed Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Ms. Witheridge died from head wounds. The UK police visit was facilitated after Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha agreed to allow British officers to assist following a meeting with Mr. Cameron.

The passage discusses Scotland's women's national football team, which has won all five qualifiers so far and is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. Victory would almost secure their place in the finals, but manager Evans is determined to avoid another play-off disappointment after previous losses. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for group standings. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically for the finals in the Netherlands, with the best six group runners-up also qualifying. Evans, a forward for Bayern Munich, emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals, a goal she shares with veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay. The team benefits from having players in top leagues worldwide, which enhances their competitiveness. Evans highlights the positive impact of playing abroad, citing the development of women's football in Germany and the competitive environment at Bayern Munich. The passage also notes the diverse locations of the Scottish squad, with players in England, Sweden, and the U.S. National Women's Soccer League.

The passage discusses Apple's response to the theft of celebrities' intimate photos from iCloud, attributed to third-party software. To enhance security, Apple has implemented a two-step verification system, which requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via the Find My iPhone app after entering a username and password. This measure prevents unauthorized access to iCloud and related services. Users can also use a 14-character recovery key if they lose their trusted device, though concerns exist about its memorability and security. The two-step verification was previously ineffective against data backups accessed via Elcomsoft's software, which is now thwarted by Apple's updates. Experts suggest making two-factor authentication the default for better security, a stance supported by Apple's plans to encourage its use more aggressively. Concerns remain about the potential loss or theft of recovery keys, but some experts downplay these risks. Apple's CEO emphasizes the importance of raising awareness about security practices.

The passage provides details on the campaign expenditures of various UK political parties during the election period from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737, while the Tories spent slightly more at £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. The total expenditure by the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087. The spending per vote was 68p for UKIP, 26p for Labour, 79p for the Conservatives, £1.45 for the Lib Dems, and 43p for the Greens. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back with experience at Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, has mutually agreed to cancel his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He could play against his former club on 18 February. Meanwhile, 21-year-old striker Keating, recommended to Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is joining after playing for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Nicholson praised Anderson for his leadership qualities and Keating for his hunger and potential despite being raw. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone but have won only one of their last six games.

The passage describes the tragic death of the 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds, who collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite narrowly beating Thistlecrack, Many Clouds was treated by veterinary staff and later pronounced dead due to a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," as confirmed by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA). Tony Welsh, the BHA's acting chief veterinary officer, noted that such incidents are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, such as overheating and "wobbling," but had not collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on the day of the race. The horse had notable past victories, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the "horse of a lifetime." Although Many Clouds had a history of overheating, the report concluded that his death was due to a rare haemorrhage, not linked to his previous condition.

The passage describes the emotional farewells of several Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) as they stand down ahead of the election on 5 May. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional during the valedictory addresses of Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond. Alex Salmond, former first minister, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the parliament's journey towards greater responsibility. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but noted it did not fulfill unionist pledges made during the referendum campaign. Salmond humorously acknowledged competing with the Chancellor's UK budget speech and wished future election candidates varying degrees of luck. He concluded by highlighting the honor of serving in the parliament and Scotland.

Duncan McNeil, a veteran Labour MSP, warned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, humorously mentioned missing her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Tricia Marwick praised both Salmond and McNeil for their distinguished service to the parliament and Scotland.

The passage describes the casting and production details for a live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson is cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father, and Emma Thompson will portray Mrs. Potts, the teapot. Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick, LeFou. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set to begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. The disaster resulted in the deaths of 96 football fans during an FA Cup semi-final at Sheffield. New inquests concluded last year that the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS is reviewing evidence files related to 23 suspects, with 15 linked to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and eight related to police conduct investigations by the Independent Police Complaints Commission. Relatives will be informed of the CPS's decisions by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division, at a private meeting in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope for accountability and acknowledged the long struggle faced by the families.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over its wall, with a former inmate describing the facility as notorious for contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the efforts of staff to prevent contraband but admits more needs to be done, prompting a review to equip prisons better to tackle these issues. A local resident reported witnessing such incidents four times in two weeks and mentioned an upcoming meeting to discuss safety measures. While a former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, the Ministry of Justice stated there is no evidence of drones at Chelmsford. New laws could result in up to two years in jail for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries in a road accident outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December. Brian Wright, 55, admitted to striking her but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and could not remember the traffic light's color when he hit Mrs. Blackburn, who was on duty escorting children across the road. Mrs. Blackburn, a much-loved figure, is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse, acknowledging the impact on her and her family. The court heard that Wright's VW Golf did not stop at a red light, and the sun was 10 minutes from setting, potentially affecting his vision. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses the situation of a middle-distance runner, Muir, who will miss the next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies. Despite finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, her exams in May conflict with the April Commonwealth Games. Muir is returning to university and prioritizes completing her degree, although she is disappointed to miss the event. She expresses confidence in the Scotland team's performance and believes she has potential for future Olympics, with the World Indoor Championships in March as a possible target. Muir is pleased with her recent performance, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m, and is optimistic about her future in athletics.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party in Dublin. A search began in Chapelizod, near the River Liffey, involving excavations expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed his case, enhancing CCTV footage from the night he vanished. The footage shows Deely speaking with a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked, and later being followed by the same man on Haddington Road. Despite releasing the footage and appealing for the man to come forward, he remains unidentified, and authorities have renewed their appeal for information.

Juan Martín del Potro secured a 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 victory over Swiss player Stan Wawrinka at Wimbledon. Del Potro, ranked 165th due to injuries, is set to play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. He expressed joy at returning to Grand Slam tennis after a long absence due to wrist surgeries. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, reached the Wimbledon semi-finals in 2013 but had not played a Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014. Meanwhile, Nick Kyrgios overcame a rain-affected match to beat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4, advancing to face Feliciano Lopez in the third round. Other matches saw Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga win their respective matches.

The passage describes Tunisia's and Morocco's challenges and resolutions regarding their participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia faced expulsion from the tournament after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a contentious penalty in their quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea during the 2015 Nations Cup. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) apologized to Caf, resolving the dispute. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 qualifying draw due to refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup over Ebola concerns, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban, reducing a fine on Morocco's FA. Both nations are now preparing for the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia set to play in Group A and Morocco in Group F. Tunisia's participation was secured after discussions with Caf president Issa Hayatou, and they aim to reach their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup, a potential record.

The passage provides an overview of McLaren's history in Formula 1, highlighting its rise and fall over the years. McLaren, a team with a storied past, has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. Despite its current struggles, the team still has two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. The decline began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design, and more recently, problems with the Honda power unit have persisted. Historically, McLaren achieved significant success with Honda in the late 1980s and early 1990s, winning 15 of 16 races in 1988. The team faced setbacks, including a scandal in 2007 involving Ferrari technical information and another in 2011 known as "lie-gate." Despite these challenges, McLaren has experienced cycles of triumph and decline. Ron Dennis, who has been a central figure in the team's management, aims to restore McLaren's former glory, believing that success is imminent. Alonso's return in 2015 was partly motivated by the potential of the renewed Honda partnership. Currently, McLaren is focused on improving its performance, with hopes of reclaiming its competitive edge in the future.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts indicated alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, and James Thomas faced one count of the same charge. A defense solicitor noted that Dungiven's licensing laws were not strictly followed, and the premises were poorly managed, operating into the morning. The judge criticized O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressed frustration over the inability to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight 3-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272, and added nine assists. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points, helping the Warriors avoid a three-game losing streak. For the Blazers, LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20 points, but Portland had already secured the Northwest Division title.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and grabbing 15 rebounds. Derrick Rose added 12 points, and the Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit with a 39-8 run in the second half. The Heat, led by Hassan Whiteside's 19 points and 16 rebounds, were outscored 57-27 after halftime, with Dwyane Wade shooting just 4 for 20. The Bulls' victory impacted Miami's playoff hopes, moving Chicago into the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference standings.

The passage describes an unexpected encounter at Liverpool's Melwood training ground involving players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic with YouTube star Bas van Velzen. Initially, the Liverpool players believed Van Velzen was a competition winner there to receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, it became apparent that Van Velzen was a skilled free-kick specialist, impressing the players with his abilities. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos showcasing his free-kick skills, delighted the Liverpool players by performing well in front of them. Balotelli and Lambert were particularly impressed, with Balotelli even executing a perfect free-kick. Van Velzen expressed his enjoyment of the experience, highlighting the satisfaction of seeing the players' reactions. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling his infamous slogan, which Balotelli had worn during a notable match in 2011.

The passage discusses the benefits of oophorectomy (ovary removal) for women diagnosed with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie. A study indicates that this procedure can reduce the risk of death from breast cancer by over 60% for BRCA1 carriers. The study analyzed 676 patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, finding a 20-year survival rate of 77.4%. Oophorectomy was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death for BRCA1 carriers, but not for BRCA2 carriers. Additionally, there was a 65% reduction in death from all causes for those who underwent the procedure. The protective effect was immediate and lasted for 15 years. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. Women with BRCA1 mutations face a 50-80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer. Genetic tests are available for those likely to have BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, or PTEN mutations, with BRCA mutations more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population. The procedure is particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer

On Easter morning, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina, shortly before 10 am. The train, No. 80, known as the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk Southern property. The couple was reportedly lingering on the tracks, possibly due to living in a homeless camp, as suggested by a man who met them while collecting scrap metal. The train, carrying 166 passengers, was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes, but no passengers were injured, although one man fell ill and received treatment. The train resumed its journey after the delay. Durham is approximately 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next stop, and the usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellín cartel member, worked as an undercover DEA operative for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. After fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss, Toro provided valuable information to the DEA, helping to take down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, the DEA did not assist him in obtaining citizenship, leaving him technically living in the U.S. illegally after retiring due to health issues. Toro faces deportation and fears for his life if returned to Colombia. His former DEA handler, Mike McManus, and a colleague have provided financial support, but Toro remains in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary. He expressed frustration, stating he has fulfilled his obligations and only seeks the promised citizenship.

The passage discusses the actions of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) in addressing concerns about the use of the ".sucks" domain by a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd. This company has been selling these domains to celebrities and companies, including Kevin Spacey, to protect their reputations, with domain names like "youtube.sucks" and "visa.sucks" being purchased. ICANN, after initially approving the ".sucks" domain, is reconsidering its stance due to complaints from industry groups and companies, labeling the practice as a "shakedown scheme." ICANN has reached out to U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. The company charges $2,499 annually for these domains, which are often resold for around $2,000. ICANN may take action against Vox Populi if their practices are found to be illegal.

A baby boy's body, found in 1988 wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, remained unidentified for 27 years. The case was reopened, and DNA analysis led to the identification of the mother, who was arrested on suspicion of infanticide. She explained that the baby was stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy, placing the baby in the pond shortly before it was discovered. The charge was dropped, and the mother remains on bail while authorities consider charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The boy was reburied in 2015 with a headstone naming him Peter, after the church. The investigation concluded with no evidence of foul play, and the mother's account was corroborated by details only she could know. The case was solved using advances in DNA technology, bringing closure to a long-standing mystery.

Kristopher Hicks, now 27, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi driven by Michael Young, 56, in Bath, Somerset, five years ago. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to evade payment and drove him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving, prompting Hicks to jump from the vehicle at over 20mph. As a result, Hicks developed epilepsy and requires round-the-clock care from his mother. Hicks' family took Young to the High Court, where Mr. Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation amount is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50% of the family's initial request. The judge acknowledged the risk created by Young's actions but reduced the damages by 50% due to Hicks' decision to jump. Hicks is also entitled to an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both parties have permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final compensation amount.

The passage describes severe weather events in Kansas and Missouri on a Wednesday night, with tornado sirens activated due to multiple storm reports. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, Kansas, which moved northeast, avoiding Wichita but posing risks to other areas. CNN's severe weather expert, Chad Myers, highlighted the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri also experienced a possible tornado in Potosi, with wind damage and flooding reported, including a fallen tree and roof damage. Nearby, unusual dark clouds were noted in Leadington, and a Twitter user in Farmington reported large hail. More storms were expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago. Rockhold is eyeing a title shot and believes he can dominate Machida by cutting him off and forcing him to fight on his terms. He respects Machida's skills and fighting style but plans to impose his own style, utilizing his speed and mixed martial arts skills to exploit Machida's perceived weaknesses. Rockhold is confident in his preparation, having trained extensively with notable fighters.

Lyoto Machida, coming off a victory against CB Dollaway, is also aiming for a title shot. He believes that by applying his style and technique, he can upset Rockhold. Machida acknowledges the potential title shot for the winner of his fight with Rockhold, noting that he has identified some weaknesses in Rockhold but prefers to assess them during the fight. Machida is confident in his preparation, having trained for eight weeks with a strong team, including Glover Teixeira.

The passage describes an incident where a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar, landed without deploying its landing gear at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane skidded on its belly, causing its propellers to ricochet off the ground and the wings to bounce. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, quickly re-engaged the engines and took off again. Despite the damage, Georgaklis managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The incident was captured on video, highlighting the unusual sounds and the pilot's quick response. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the cause, which could be human error or a mechanical fault. Georgaklis, who has over 50 years of flying experience, was accompanied by his dog, Buddy.

Manuel Pellegrini, the manager of Manchester City, has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has committed to supporting him until the end of the season. Despite criticism of Toure's performances amid City's defensive struggles, Pellegrini emphasized Toure's importance to the team. Sportsmail reported that City would consider offers for Toure in the summer as they plan to revamp their aging squad. Toure, who has two years left on his contract, is determined to stay. Meanwhile, City faces West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany due to a muscle injury. Joe Hart, City's goalkeeper, acknowledged the team's underperformance and emphasized player responsibility, while also supporting Pellegrini. Sam Allardyce, West Ham's manager, has warned Aaron Cresswell about potential interest from City and Chelsea, noting that previous players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair did not succeed at City.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "godfather of Uxbridge," was set to be extradited to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence for being a member of Cosa Nostra. However, his sentence was dropped because Italian law extinguishes a sentence if more than double the penalty time has passed, which occurred in October 2014. Despite his conviction remaining intact, the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction due to its age, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. Rancadore, who lived in the UK for over 20 years, will remain in the UK. The case will still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. The UK Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) acknowledged a procedural error in failing to appeal a district judge's decision in March 2014, which contributed to the delay in extradition proceedings. Legal experts criticized the time and resources spent on the case, noting that the Italian authorities could not enforce the sentence from October 2014. Rancadore, who lived under the alias Marc Skinner, will now live peacefully in England with his family.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of the three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Paul Nicholls-trained Mr. Mole will compete against six rivals, including Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This race will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One event, with his final day as a professional jockey's schedule to be finalized on Friday morning. McCoy announced his retirement after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other competitors include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The passage describes the tragic murder of Marcy Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcy, who was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcy's body was discovered 33 days after she disappeared, and her mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, was advised against seeing the body or crime scene photos by her then-husband. Despite this, Ritter recently viewed the crime scene photos and expressed a desire for revenge, describing the horrific state of her daughter's body. The case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006, convicted of second-degree murder in 2009, and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The murder took place near Marcy's home, and her body was found in a rarely used garage. Barrett had a history of sex charges and was in prison during the time of Marcy's disappearance, except for a brief period.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He considers his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons about his game. McIlroy aims to become the sixth player to win all four major titles, joining the ranks of Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is determined to win at Augusta, viewing it as a career-long goal. He acknowledges the challenge of winning on different courses with varying conditions but remains hopeful of achieving this milestone. McIlroy's success last year, despite personal and legal distractions, was aided by using the golf course as a sanctuary. He hopes to replicate this focus at Augusta, despite the surrounding hype.

The passage summarizes several trending stories from a busy week:

1. **Rainbows in New York**: After heavy rain, four rainbows appeared across the New York sky, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company.

2. **Exotic Dancers in China**: In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is common, but this practice is now under scrutiny due to a crackdown on vice.

3. **R.D. Jefe's Interview**: R.D. Jefe became agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his private life.

4. **Lip Plumping Trend**: A new trend involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar, inspired by Kylie Jenner, with the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge.

5. **Alice Barker's Time Travel**: Filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker relive her past.

6. **Prom-posal Controversy**: A school rejected a prom-posal referencing bombs, with accusations of racism against the administrators.

7. **Beauty and the Beast Casting**: Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere, generating social media interest.

8. **Johnny Depp in 'Black Mass'**: Johnny Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the trailer.

9. **Unique Pregnancy Announcement**: A pregnancy was

The passage highlights alarming new figures revealing that 272 children were hospitalized in England last year due to brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). Experts warn that the actual number affected could be much higher. Research by the World Health Organization suggests that at least 1 in 100 babies in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical issues due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 annually. Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome emphasizes that FAS is a significant, under-diagnosed problem. The case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who struggles with daily tasks and will never live independently due to FAS, illustrates the syndrome's impact. Other medical issues linked to prenatal alcohol exposure include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. While the government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption to up to two units no more than twice a week, Mitchell advocates for a complete abstinence recommendation.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, an ex-juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," was jailed for six years after attempting to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham. On March 15, at 8 pm, the masked 31-year-old entered Shildon Post Office and Stores, wielding an axe and demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. The robbery was thwarted when owner Sab Dhillon tackled him, causing him to fall and drop the axe. Sab's wife, Sam, assisted by hitting McKerry twice with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. The police arrived shortly after and arrested McKerry, who had previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery. Known for repeatedly returning home after committing crimes, McKerry had a history of offenses, including shoplifting from age 12, 80 arrests by age 15, and convictions for various crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors are charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks and must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, near Halifax, where they received bail conditions requiring them to live at the nearby Stadacona Naval Base, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy. The accused—Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley—were involved in a hockey tournament at the Shearwater Naval Base before the alleged incident on April 10. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, with potential penalties of up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, and additional charges may arise from forensic tests. The British government has agreed to allow them to continue their employment, and they are prohibited from contacting the victim and six witnesses. The case is being assisted by the British High Commission, with the Royal Navy deciding on their employment status during the legal proceedings.

The passage describes the experience of Valerie Jackson, whose son, R.J. Jackson, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that makes his skin appear red and scaly. R.J. is one of only 70 people worldwide with this condition. Valerie was shocked when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse, mistaking R.J.'s symptoms for signs of scalding. This incident occurred while she was applying creams to R.J.'s skin in a Walmart in Las Vegas. Valerie and her husband, Reginald, regularly apply creams to manage R.J.'s symptoms, which include red, inflamed, and scaly skin. Despite the challenges, Valerie finds R.J. to be a beautiful and happy child. Netherton's syndrome is a severe form of ichthyosis, and while there is no cure, symptoms may improve over time. Valerie discovered the condition through an online support group after initially struggling to find information. She faces ongoing criticism and ignorance from others, but remains committed to caring for her son and raising awareness about his condition.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's advertising campaign featuring a bikini-clad model with the slogan "Are you beach body ready?" The ads, displayed on the London Underground, sparked backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, leading to a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). Transport for London (TfL) announced the removal of the posters, citing the end of the paid advertising period and noting the public reaction. Protein World defended the campaign, claiming the image was unphotoshopped and engaging in social media debates. The controversy also led to a protest in Hyde Park and discussions on TV shows like "Good Morning Britain," where Protein World's head of global marketing defended the campaign. The ASA is assessing complaints to determine further action. The incident highlights the growing market for protein products in the UK, with sales expected to increase significantly.

Rail firms are facing criticism for planning fare increases of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the London-Cotswolds route, which affects his Witney constituency. Cameron and Labour have both promised to freeze or cap fare hikes. FGW's planned changes would raise the cost of an off-peak return from Charlbury to London from £33.30 to £62.40, an 87% increase. Cameron has personally intervened due to constituent anger. Train companies can increase "unregulated" fares three times a year, which include off-peak and advance-purchase tickets.
