Moric, however, denied these claims on Instagram, stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was treated in the hospital for a domestic accident. She posted photos of her injuries and reassured her followers that she was recovering at home. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially confirmed the suicide attempt, but Moric clarified that he was in Naples at the time. She expressed shock at the reports and mentioned a previous false claim in 2009. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a famous paparazzi, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria. Corona was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photos.

As Kate and William prepare for the arrival of their second child, the British public is hopeful they will choose a traditional name. A YouGov poll for The Sunday Times indicates that Diana, after William's mother, is the favorite name for a girl, with 12% of respondents supporting it. Alice and Charlotte follow, each with 9% preference. Alice is named after the Queen's late aunt, and Charlotte is a nod to William's father, Charles. If the child is a boy, 13% prefer the name James, with Alexander as the second choice. A quarter of the 2,200 people polled desire a female baby, while only 3% hope for a younger brother for Prince George. Social media users also express a strong preference for naming a girl after Diana. Additionally, 68% of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, specifically in the city of Khost, on Thursday, resulting in 17 deaths and 63 injuries. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. Among the injured was an Afghan lawmaker participating in the protests. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other group has claimed it. The protesters, including an Afghan member of parliament for Khost province, were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The report was contributed to by CNN's Masoud Popalzai, Jethro Mullen, and Elizabeth Joseph.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer, as confirmed by his representative, Dinorah Santana. Alves, a Brazilian right-back, has had a successful seven-year tenure at Barcelona, winning four La Liga titles and two UEFA Champions League titles. At 31, he has been unable to agree on a new deal with the club and will depart from Nou Camp. His agent, who is also his ex-wife, stated that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension contingent on playing in 60% of matches, and declared that negotiations are over. Santana criticized the club for not renewing Alves's contract earlier in the season.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old player at Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has quickly become a fan favorite by scoring three goals in six games, believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a great fit for Boca Juniors due to their playing style and abilities. He suggests that Boca's fans would be thrilled to see them play at La Bombonera. Osvaldo highlights Pirlo's status as one of the best midfielders in the world and Totti's legendary status at Roma, suggesting that Totti would be equally adored in Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton, which has gone viral online. Despite the incident, he received no special treatment at Paul Nicholls' yard and continued his usual duties, mucking out stables, with only a cut on his nose as a reminder. Ferguson expressed that the fall was a blur and he only realized what happened after watching a replay. Fellow jockeys checked on him, and he acknowledged his luck in escaping serious injury. The incident has garnered him some online attention, including a few hundred new Twitter followers. Ferguson remains undeterred and plans to continue riding, even joking about a potential gymnastics career due to his acrobatic fall.

The passage discusses the release of the movie "The Avengers: Age of Ultron," which premiered at Westfield London shopping centre. James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, participated in the movie's hype by posting an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man, referencing the film's star Robert Downey Jr. Haskell, an England flanker, returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and the Highlanders in New Zealand. Since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for Wasps and has earned 57 caps for England. Haskell's rugby career has included stints in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a key trend for the spring/summer 2015 (SS15) season. These trousers, available in various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped, offer an effortless alternative to the long-dominant skinny jeans. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp and Emma advocate for the wide-leg look, emphasizing its ability to provide a fresh style while maintaining proportion with simple tops and high heels. The trend, which has roots in the 1970s, is highlighted on runways by designers like Gucci and Celine, with high-street options available from Topshop. The passage suggests pairing wide-leg trousers with simple knits or shirts to avoid overwhelming the outfit and recommends high-waisted, longer lengths for added leg length. Denim is noted as the easiest way to adopt the trend, with brands like Finery London offering more affordable options. The trend is versatile, suitable for various occasions, and does not require warm weather.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students had signed a petition against showing the movie as part of UMIX, a series of social events for students, due to concerns that it negatively depicted the Iraq War and the Middle East. The university's Detroit metropolitan area has the largest Arab-American population in the nation. However, there was a backlash to the initial decision to cancel the screening, leading to a counter-petition. E. Royster Harper, the university's vice president for student life, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression. The university will also offer a screening of the family-friendly film "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper." The decision to proceed with the screening was praised by Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

The passage describes an incident where two French tourists allegedly set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, which survived but was singed, is a small marsupial found on some islands off the Western Australian coast, including Rottnest Island. Following the incident, detectives questioned the two men, aged 18 and 24, and seized video evidence. Both men, residing in Cockburn Central, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty, with a court appearance scheduled for April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen footage of herself dancing despite being filmed. Her photographs and memorabilia were lost over the years. With the help of filmmakers, including Mark Cantor from jazz-on-film.com, a video of "soundies" (early music videos) featuring Barker was compiled and shown to her at her nursing home. Barker was delighted to finally see herself dancing, describing the experience as "just fabulous."

The passage discusses the decline in the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain. New figures indicate that a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car. The study, conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV, surveyed 1,100 adults and found that only 12% of men who do wash their cars do so regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the size of modern vehicles like 4x4s. Despite this trend, car washing increases during holidays, with 15 million cars cleaned during the Easter break. The practice is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are more likely to wash their cars themselves, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are less likely to do so. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley notes that the tradition has faded due to time constraints, larger cars, and the availability of alternative car washing options.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's significant impact on him since Gerrard joined Liverpool in 2008, acknowledging Gerrard as one of the best players in the world and synonymous with the club. Gerrard, set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aims to conclude his Liverpool career by reaching the final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel credits Gerrard for helping him settle at Liverpool when he joined from Zenit St. Petersburg in 2008. Although Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, he believes the club has potential replacements for the iconic midfielder. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the lineup for the match against Villa after serving three-match bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, adding to his legendary career. He achieved this feat on the 130-yard fourth hole, with the shot spinning back into the hole. Nicklaus was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Despite his ace, Nicklaus's achievement was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who also made two holes-in-one that day. Nicklaus became the youngest to win the Masters in 1963 and won his sixth green jacket in 1986. He is one of five golfers to complete the career grand slam, a feat Rory McIlroy could achieve with a third consecutive major win.

The passage describes severe weather events in Kansas and Missouri on a Wednesday night, with tornado sirens activated due to multiple storm reports. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, Kansas, and moved northeast, posing risks to other areas. CNN's severe weather expert, Chad Myers, highlighted the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri also experienced a possible tornado in Potosi, with reports of wind damage and flooding, including a fallen tree and roof damage. Nearby, unusual dark clouds were noted in Leadington, and a Twitter user in Farmington reported large hail. More storms were expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the fatal shooting of Eric Harris, whom he claimed he intended to subdue with a taser but accidentally shot with a gun. Bates was granted permission by a judge to vacation in the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as apathetic. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Bates, working for the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office during a weapons sting operation, has apologized to the Harris family, as has Sheriff Stanley Glanz. Bates's lawyer claims he had proper training, while the Harris family's lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and connections. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies allegations of forged records, and two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats. Bates's training documents were released by his lawyer to support his defense.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against José Aldo on July 11, where he will challenge Aldo for his title in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, McGregor unveiled a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, accompanied by the caption, "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor, 26, has also previously inked a gorilla eating a heart on his chest. He has expressed that Aldo lacks the same motivation to fight as he does, claiming Aldo does not want the belt in his presence. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 supporters, highlighting their tense relationship. McGregor believes he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after skolling a beer at an Australian rules function. Critics, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argued that his actions glorified binge drinking and reinforced the stereotype that masculinity is linked to heavy drinking. Abbott, cheered on by a crowd, downed a schooner in about six seconds, which was seen as promoting a culture focused on drinking speed and quantity rather than socializing. Opposition leader Bill Shorten made a light-hearted comment about Abbott's drinking habits, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, emphasizing his fitness routine. Abbott's actions were compared to former Prime Minister Bob Hawke's, but Robert noted that attitudes towards binge drinking have shifted, suggesting Abbott should have been more considerate of current concerns. Abbott's speech to the players highlighted his enthusiasm for the event, and he was praised by the crowd for his drinking feat.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, linked to intravenous drug use and the opioid Opana. This outbreak has prompted a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence, which began on March 26 and is set to end on April 25. Since its start, 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed, and about 1,400 used syringes have been returned. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. The program's future and potential expansion to other counties are uncertain, as Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. Senate President Pro Tem David Long and others are considering whether to support legislation allowing needle exchanges in counties with high hepatitis C rates, a key indicator of needle-sharing and potential HIV outbreaks. The bill passed the House on April 7 and is under review. Funding remains a concern, as the federal government has banned public funding for such programs since 1989, and Pence's order did not allocate funds for Scott County.

The passage describes an incident where an Arsenal fan boyfriend quizzed his girlfriend, Saskia, on her knowledge of his favorite football club, Arsenal. She scored 43.5 out of 50, which he humorously graded as an 'A', and decided not to end their relationship. Saskia shared the test on Twitter, where she expressed mixed feelings with emoticons. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables, and sections for personal responses, with instructions like "read every question at least twice." Despite scoring 87%, her boyfriend noted areas for improvement, such as learning player positions and understanding rivalries. The test also humorously asked why Arsenal is the best team in English football, to which she answered with references to their FA Cup wins and Thierry Henry. While some Twitter users praised the boyfriend as a "legend" and commended Saskia's knowledge, others felt the quiz was excessive. Overall, the event was seen as a fun, albeit intense, way to test her football knowledge.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellín cartel member, worked as an undercover DEA operative for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. After fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss, Toro provided valuable information to the DEA, helping to take down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, the DEA did not assist him in obtaining citizenship, leaving him technically living in the U.S. illegally after retiring due to health issues. Toro faces deportation, which he fears will lead to his death if he returns to Colombia. Despite his situation, he has received some support, including a $5,000 payment from a former colleague for an operation. Currently, Toro is in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary. He remains hopeful for the U.S. citizenship that was promised to him.

The passage describes a tragic incident involving a 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh, India, who allegedly suffered a gang rape by five men from her village. Following the attack, her family reportedly pressured her to remain silent. In response, she set herself on fire with kerosene, resulting in 70% burns, and is now in critical condition at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The accused men have been arrested. The incident highlights the heightened sensitivity in India regarding sexual assault, especially after the government banned a documentary about the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old student, Jyoti Singh, in Delhi. This case led to widespread protests and international outrage, resulting in the death sentences for four men involved in her murder. The passage also mentions other related incidents of sexual violence and vigilante justice in India, reflecting ongoing societal tensions and calls for better protection for women.

Louis van Gaal, Manchester United manager, expressed his desire to win against Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford, despite the absence of Robin van Persie due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal emphasized that while most players are fit, he has a different standard for fitness, ruling out both Van Persie and Luke Shaw. United has the opportunity to finish as high as second or third in the league, which would secure a top-four position and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal highlighted the importance of the match for climbing the table and acknowledged City's challenge, while downplaying revenge motives from a previous loss. He also praised the support of United fans and expressed excitement about experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford. Key players like Wayne Rooney, Angel Di Maria, Radamel Falcao, and Ander Herrera are preparing for the game.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match at the Emirates Stadium. This protest followed the Premier League's announcement of a £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, criticizing the high ticket prices, which started at £64 for the 12:45 PM kick-off, one of the highest in the league. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. Kelvin Meadows of the Black Scarf Movement described ticket prices as "extortionate" and criticized the commercialization of football. Roy Bentham of Spirit of Shankly called for reductions in ticket prices to align with working-class earnings, warning of losing future generations of fans if changes aren't made. Further protests were anticipated after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader, diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth, was saved by a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader. Star's condition, characterized by blocked bile ducts, was identified when her skin turned yellow, a symptom of jaundice. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock the ducts, a liver transplant became necessary. Neither parent was a suitable match, but Shanell offered part of her liver, saving Star's life. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since made a good recovery, though she requires regular blood tests and anti-rejection medication. Biliary atresia, affecting about 1 in 16,000 babies, can lead to liver failure if untreated, with the Kasai procedure being a common treatment. Shanell's selfless act was driven by familial love, and she expressed no hesitation in helping her niece.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in Audi's football challenge, competing against teammates Loïc Rémy and Willian. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by hitting balls into a car's boot from close range. The second challenge involved playing football over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus on a makeshift tennis court, which Hazard and Ake won, leading 6-0. The final challenge required shooting from long range to hit balls through the top of a convertible Audi. Rémy and Willian won this round, with Willian accidentally smashing a car's wing mirror, which he later laughed about. Despite the mishap, Rémy and Willian secured a surprise victory in the final challenge.

The passage describes the sentencing of Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, for a highway crash in December 2013 that resulted in the deaths of a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, 54, claimed during his sentencing that he was not suicidal, despite prosecutors' claims that he intended to kill himself by driving his truck across a median at high speed. The crash occurred in Lebanon, New Hampshire, and Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger's wife testified to his character, and his defense cited his health issues, including ambien withdrawal and multiple sclerosis, as factors. Dellinger had previously held high-level positions at several major companies and had left his job due to health reasons. The victims' families were devastated, and Dellinger's actions have also led to a wrongful death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears, from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt. She was spared the maximum sentence of 25 years to life. During the sentencing, Spears showed no emotion, which was noted by her ex-husband, Chris Hill, who expressed anger and frustration on Facebook, wishing for her to die in prison. Hill criticized her lack of emotion and accused her of being cruel. The judge acknowledged Spears' mental illness but described the crime as unfathomably cruel. Prosecutors argued that Spears sought attention by making her son ill, while her lawyer claimed she was a hardworking mother and blamed hospital negligence, planning to appeal the verdict. Spears, who lived in Chestnut Ridge, New York, was held at Westchester County Jail. Prosecutors highlighted Spears' social media posts about her son's medical issues as evidence, which included photos of his final hours on life support. Spears did not testify at the trial.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, prompted by the emergence of two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine, delayed by a month, now includes protection against these strains due to the previous vaccine's ineffectiveness. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasizes the importance of vaccination for everyone, as the new vaccine also protects against H1N1. He advises booking flu shots promptly despite the delay, highlighting the need to protect high-risk individuals by vaccinating those around them. The modified vaccine is expected to better match circulating strains globally, aiming to prevent more deaths.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by the caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois. They are dealing with criticism from a National Geographic article, which described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby," and potential budget cuts that threaten the site's management. These issues arise as the state commemorates the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. Illinois is experiencing a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, suggesting it be merged with another department. The tomb has undergone significant renovations, costing over $2.5 million, and is in excellent physical condition. Despite these improvements, reduced hours and staffing due to funding cuts have led to operational challenges. Supporters of the site argue that the National Geographic portrayal is unfair, while some visitors, like William Sparks, find the tomb impressive. The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has been reconstructed multiple times to improve its foundation and public access.

The passage discusses the resurgence of various fashion trends from the nineties and noughties, highlighting both their past popularity and current comeback. Key trends include:

1. **JNCO Jeans**: Known for their wide leg openings, these jeans are making a comeback, despite their impracticality.
2. **Bucket Hats**: Originally worn by fishermen and farmers, they gained popularity in the nineties and early noughties, with celebrities like Rihanna keeping the trend alive.
3. **Camouflage Print**: Once favored by Destiny's Child, it continues to appear in modern wardrobes, as seen with Jourdan Dunn.
4. **Extreme Trends**: Styles like designer prints and double denim were popularized by celebrities such as Victoria Beckham and are now embraced by Kylie Jenner.
5. **Ugg Boots**: A noughties staple worn by Paris Hilton, they remain popular with celebrities like Kristen Bell.
6. **Daisy Dukes**: Tiny denim shorts popularized by Jessica Simpson are still worn by Miley Cyrus.
7. **Juicy Couture Tracksuits**: Once worn by Nicole Richie and Britney Spears, they are still in style with celebrities like Nicki Minaj.
8. **Colored Sunglasses**: A nineties trend for boy bands and pop

The passage summarizes several trending stories from a busy week:

1. **Rainbows in New York**: After heavy rain, four rainbows appeared across the New York sky, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company.

2. **China's Crackdown on Vice**: Exotic dancers at wakes in rural China are now targeted by a crackdown on vice, forcing families to find new ways to cheer up mourners.

3. **R.D. J's Interview**: R.D. J became agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his private life.

4. **Kylie Jenner Lip Plumping Trend**: A new trend involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar, inspired by Kylie Jenner, with the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge.

5. **Alice Barker's Time Travel**: Filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker relive her past.

6. **Prom-posal Controversy**: A school rejected a prom-posal referencing bombs, with accusations of racism against administrators.

7. **Beauty and the Beast Cast**: Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere, adding to the social media buzz around the cast.

8. **Johnny Depp in 'Black Mass'**: Johnny Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the trailer.

9. **

The passage describes events at the Miami Open, highlighting Serena Williams' achievement of her 700th career victory, celebrated with a giant cake. This followed Andy Murray's 500th win, which was also marked with a cake. Williams advanced to the semi-finals by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3). Her hopes of facing her sister Venus were dashed due to Venus's defeat by Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams, ranked world No. 1, aims to progress in what is considered her hometown event. She will face Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens, in the semi-finals. The passage also notes Williams' previous defeat to Lisicki at Wimbledon 2013 and her intent to avenge it. Additionally, it mentions the celebrations and interactions between players, including Williams posing with her cake and Lisicki and Williams shaking hands post-match.

Sabeen Mahmud was a prominent figure in Pakistan known for her advocacy of free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. She operated a second-floor café in Karachi, which served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and progressive values. Despite the dangers associated with free speech in Pakistan, Mahmud was a vocal advocate for non-violence and progressive values, making her a national figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance. Tragically, she was shot dead by gunmen at her café, along with her mother, who was also injured. Mahmud had recently led a discussion on the sensitive topic of Baluchistan, a region plagued by insurgency and allegations of mass abductions, which many wanted silenced. Her café, known as T2F, was a sanctuary for those seeking secular wisdom and freedom of thought. Her death sparked widespread grief and gratitude for her work, with many expressing their sorrow and admiration on social media. No one has claimed responsibility for her murder, and no motive has been named by the police. Mahmud's bravery and commitment to open dialogue left a lasting impact on those who knew her and followed her work.

The passage describes the plight of Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee in Indian Kashmir, who has lived there for 70 years without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote in state elections. Mangu Ram and approximately 100,000 other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) have been denied these rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. Despite living in India, these refugees are classified as second-class citizens because of a pre-independence law that restricts citizenship to those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), a Hindu nationalist party, has won a share of power in Kashmir, raising hopes for the WPRs that their status might be normalized. Activists like Labha Ram Gandhi emphasize the need for state-subject rights to improve their conditions, warning that the community is prepared to fight for their rights if necessary. The passage also highlights the ongoing conflict in Kashmir, which remains one of India's more prosperous states despite the unrest.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a move to Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer for him. Muto is open to being loaned to Vitesse Arnhem but desires a club where he can play regularly and develop. FC Tokyo's president, Naoki Ogane, confirmed the offer, while Muto himself expressed the need to carefully consider his options, prioritizing a team that suits his development goals. Real Zaragoza's former manager, Ranko Popovic, praised Muto's intelligence, speed, and confidence, highlighting his potential for success at Chelsea. Chelsea's manager, José Mourinho, acknowledged Muto's abilities but emphasized the club's focus on financial fair play and acquiring quality players. Chelsea's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber also influences their transfer strategy.

The passage discusses Australia's decision to drop the policy of not selecting players who play overseas, contrasting it with England's outdated approach. Stuart Lancaster, England's coach, is criticized for not picking the best players regardless of where they play, unlike other sports where such restrictions don't apply. The passage highlights players like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage, who have improved significantly while playing for Toulon in France, suggesting they should be considered for the Wallabies and England teams, respectively. It argues that players like Jonny Wilkinson and Nick Abendanon have also improved overseas, emphasizing that the best players should be selected for the World Cup to maximize England's chances of success. The passage concludes by praising Australia for recognizing the importance of selecting the best talent available, regardless of their club affiliations.

The passage describes the FireChat app, which allows users to chat without internet or mobile signals by utilizing a wireless mesh network. This network is facilitated by Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) in iOS 7 and a similar feature in Android, enabling message and photo sharing within Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct range. FireChat, downloaded over five million times, is useful in areas without connectivity, like planes or underground, and helps save on data plans. It offers secure, anonymous messaging by using app usernames instead of mobile numbers, and its "everyone" setting extends message reach by relaying data across nodes.

To address the range limitations of FireChat, Open Garden developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon to strengthen these off-the-grid networks. Greenstone extends the range of FireChat by holding messages until another device comes within range, with a battery life of one year and the capacity to store up to 1,000 recent messages. It is currently in development and works within a 20-foot range. Open Garden's CMO, Christophe Daligault, highlights its potential for resilient communication in various scenarios, such as neighborhoods, hospitals, and large events. The device's future availability depends on partnerships with manufacturers.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, aims to change the negative connotations associated with the word "fat" by embracing it as a body-positive descriptor. In a TED Talk, she highlighted that terms like "short" and "wife" are honest descriptions, and similarly, "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly." Bustle noted that societal pressures often lead women to deny being fat, as it is perceived negatively. Despite a rise in size discrimination in the workplace and young girls' desires to be thinner, Bustle believes exposure to body diversity can foster acceptance and preference for different body types. Her burlesque performances aim to positively showcase fuller figures, challenging societal norms of desirability. Inspired by another performer, Beelzebabe, Bustle, who weighs 240 lbs, found empowerment in burlesque, which she began in 2012. Her TED Talk, posted on YouTube in 2014, has received mostly positive feedback, with nearly 38,000 views and messages of support, including from a teenage girl who shared the video with her sister, prompting them to rethink their body image. Bustle emphasizes the importance of finding personal "courage references" to boost self-esteem.

The passage describes Theo Walcott's frequent appearances on the Arsenal bench throughout the season, as he has been overlooked for most games. Despite this, he has been involved in a photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, along with runway model Olga Sherer, for Paris's oldest fashion house, Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott, who has been on the substitutes' bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games, came on for the last six minutes of a 0-0 draw with Chelsea. He hopes to start in Arsenal's upcoming match against Hull after his last start in a 3-0 win over West Ham. Arsenal's first team will wear similar attire to the photoshoot for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa.

The passage describes an auction of a collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, set to take place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on PropStore.com on May 29. The collection, valued at an estimated $746,100, includes over 400 items from more than 50 productions, including "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," and "How the Grinch Stole Christmas." Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" (valued at $40,000), the Two-Face mask from "Batman Forever" (valued at $1,500), and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" (valued at $8,000). Other items from films like "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," "Batman & Robin," "Hellboy," and "Mighty Joe Young" will also be auctioned. The auction offers fans and collectors a chance to own pieces of Hollywood history, with some items expected to fetch more than their estimated values. Rick Baker's 30-year career includes work on numerous iconic films, and the auction is presented as a unique opportunity to acquire his creations.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, tragically died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his family while skiing. Described as daring, outgoing, and determined, Carwyn fell over a 164-foot drop into dense woodland. His family, from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, described him as a competent skier and snowboarder who loved the mountains. The accident occurred during what was described as a happy ski holiday in Flaine. Carwyn's mother, Cari, and siblings were skiing when he went missing. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. The family expressed their devastation, describing a "vast void in their hearts." Carwyn was known for his love of adventure, modeling himself after Bear Grylls. The community in Wales, including his school and local officials, expressed their grief and support for the family. Carwyn's body was prepared for repatriation, while his friends and schoolmates mourned his loss.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to pressures to be a "size zero." Obsessed with her weight, she restricted her diet to just one piece of fruit a day, hiding food and lying to her mother. Her dramatic weight loss led to her collapsing and being placed on a heart monitor in intensive care. Laura's struggle began at age 13 after being bullied for her weight, feeling pressured by societal standards. Despite agreeing to a "sensible diet" with her mother, she became more obsessive, reducing her calorie intake drastically. Her health deteriorated, leading to hospitalization. After recovery, Laura worked with eating disorder teams and participated in Miss Teen GB, which promotes positive body image. The passage highlights the serious mental health condition of anorexia, its prevalence, and the importance of support and awareness.

The passage describes Liverpool's unveiling of their new home kit, designed by New Balance, at Anfield. This kit marks the beginning of a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal with New Balance, replacing Warrior as the club's supplier. The event featured players like Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, who presented the kit to fans. Despite Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract, Liverpool fans expressed their desire for him to stay, and the club is determined to retain him. The new kit includes a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims with the memorial flame and number 96. Liverpool legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended the launch. The kit features all-white branding and a new collar style. Sterling and Sturridge emphasized the importance of fan support and expressed hopes for success in the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

The passage describes the creation of the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, produced by researchers from the University of Manchester. This map is the first in a series aimed at providing a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. The map, which shows clumps of dark matter over 0.4% of the sky, was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile. The goal is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. Dark matter, which makes up about 80% of the universe's matter, is invisible but detectable through its gravitational effects on visible matter. The map helps study galaxy formation and the nature of dark energy, which is believed to cause the universe's accelerated expansion. The project is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, which uses gravitational lensing to observe dark matter's effects. The map was released at the American Physical Society meeting in Baltimore, and the survey has completed its second year.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to acquire the 21-year-old Dutch international as one of his first signings. Van Gaal, familiar with Depay's abilities from the 2014 World Cup, where he was part of the Netherlands squad that finished third, is interested in bringing him to the club. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, has been a key player for PSV, which won the Dutch championship for the first time in seven years. Despite interest from Tottenham and Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United appears to be in a strong position to sign him. Depay, born in 1994, began his career at VV Moordrecht and moved to PSV at age 12, making his first-team debut in 2011. Known for his pace, dribbling, and shooting ability, he has been compared to Arjen Robben and even Cristiano Ronaldo by scouts and managers. Depay has also been recognized internationally, having scored in the 2014 World Cup and been nominated for the tournament's best young player award.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team, taking a commanding lead back to West London. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, with Dominic Solanke adding a late goal to seal the win. Abraham's performance was notable, scoring his 35th and 36th goals of the season, though he was substituted due to injury. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalized in the first half, but Chelsea's defense, including Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, effectively neutralized City's threats. Key players for City included Kean Bryan, who was injured, and Brandon Barker, who created chances but couldn't capitalize. Chelsea's Charlie Colkett and Ola Aina were influential in midfield and defense, respectively.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, has stated that people are "born with a sexual preference" and believes that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He argues that state legislators, not courts, should decide on the legality of same-sex marriage, emphasizing that states have historically regulated marriage. Rubio has expressed that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, despite not agreeing with the decision, out of respect for their choice. He reiterated his belief that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Additionally, Rubio, a Catholic, believes divorce is wrong but would continue to love someone if they were divorced. He announced his presidential run and has reportedly secured significant financial commitments for the campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia, embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda, driven by their dream to explore the planet "a pedal at a time." After leaving their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they have been traveling as economically as possible, covering nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries in 356 days. They live on less than three euros per day, primarily by camping (161 nights out of 256) and using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their main expenses are food, costing about 2.74 euros per person per day. They sustain themselves with inexpensive staples like pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, and seasonal produce, supplemented by meals from locals and foraged or dumpster-dived food. Starting in London, they have cycled through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey, and are now heading into Asia, with plans to eventually cycle across the Pacific and the Americas. Their journey is documented on their blog, "The Crazy Travel."

A couple from Texas, who married in 2012, claims their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed racial slurs on photo booth snapshots. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, is suing Evans under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. The incident was discovered months after the wedding when the bride's sister informed them. Evans allegedly responded to the complaint with "sue me" and denied any wrongdoing, claiming no evidence links the company to the offensive captions. The couple seeks an apology, and mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if no agreement is reached. The wedding took place at the Beautiful Bell Tower in Northwest Houston.

Mike Brown, the England full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, which occurred after the France game. He remains uncertain about his return date after withdrawing from Harlequins' match against Saracens. Brown is determined not to rush his recovery to avoid an extended break, similar to those experienced by players like Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling. He emphasizes the importance of being cautious, especially with significant matches approaching.

Brown was concussed during England's victory over Italy in February and had hoped to recover in time for the Ireland game in March but withdrew due to symptoms. He credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, gained from world rugby online modules, for his decision to prioritize health over playing. Brown advocates for honesty and caution regarding concussion symptoms, urging teammates to avoid playing if they exhibit such symptoms. He spoke at the launch of Land Rover's "We Deal in Real" campaign, which aims to highlight grassroots rugby clubs. George North, another player, has been advised not to play this season after suffering multiple concussions.

The passage suggests that smartphone use may contribute to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples. Research indicates that the frequency of sex among Britons has decreased since the emergence of the internet. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, notes in his book "Sex by Numbers" that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. He attributes this decline to the integration of public and private lives, with constant connectivity leading to busier lives and less time for intimate moments. Spiegelhalter also mentions that living alone and competing demands on time, such as work emails, contribute to sex falling lower on the list of priorities. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, supports this by stating that late-night work emails can prevent people from focusing on their partners at bedtime.

The passage describes the dramatic decline in popularity and value of Tibetan Mastiffs in China. Once highly prized and capable of commanding prices up to £1.2 million, these dogs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin. This decline is partly attributed to China's anti-corruption crackdown, which has reduced the practice of gifting these dogs to officials. Additionally, bans on owning large dogs in major cities have impacted their popularity. The collapse of the mastiff market was highlighted when animal-welfare workers rescued dogs being transported to a slaughterhouse. The passage also notes that unscrupulous breeders have compromised the breed's quality through cross-breeding for profit, leading to a surplus of poor-quality dogs. The rapid urbanization in China has further contributed to the breed's unsuitability for city living.

The passage describes a survey conducted in Paris, where every woman surveyed reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transport. Half of these women were assaulted before the age of 18. The survey, which included 600 women, highlighted a range of harassment from insults to severe attacks, leading to widespread fear among women, with six out of ten feeling afraid of being attacked on public transport. This fear often forces women to alter their daily routines to avoid harassment, effectively excluding them from public spaces. The findings prompted calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains. The report, presented to the French women's rights ministry, emphasized the need for women to move freely in public spaces without fear. It also highlighted the importance of educating women and the public about the severity of such harassment and the legal consequences for perpetrators.

The passage describes a competition called #everydayfix, organized by Leeds-based Direct Line, which invited groups to design prototype products addressing common everyday emergencies. The competition was part of the Direct Line Everyday Fix Design Makeathon, where participants identified top "everyday emergencies" through a survey of 2,000 people. The top issues included not being able to sleep, losing keys, and being stuck in traffic.

Three prototype products were shortlisted: 

1. **Snooze**: An alarm clock designed by Instruments that connects with your phone to silence notifications, ensuring a good night's sleep.
2. **Forget Me Lock**: Created by Onn Studio, this device attaches to a key and indicates whether a door is locked (red) or open (green).
3. **Nipper**: The world's smallest mobile phone charger, designed by Impulse, which uses household batteries to charge phones.

The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag, with the most retweeted product by April 46th going into a Kickstarter campaign for development. Other ideas not shortlisted included a parking pin, a relay app for message forwarding, and a smart helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for awarding over £500,000 of public funds to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, of which she is a director. The charity, which supports crime victims, also includes Sue Sim, Northumbria's Chief Constable, on its board. This arrangement has drawn criticism, with accusations of a conflict of interest and the creation of a "soap opera" within the force. Keith Vaz, Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, criticized the decision, stating it was inappropriate for a PCC to use public money for an organization in which they have an interest. Baird defended her actions, asserting adherence to Ministry of Justice protocols. Sim, who gained prominence for her role in the Raoul Moat manhunt, announced her retirement from the force, citing a desire to spend more time with her family. The Ministry of Justice confirmed it would investigate potential conflicts of interest. The charity was established after a decline in contacts with its predecessor, Victim Support, and concerns have been raised about potential reluctance to use a service partly run by Sim, who faced misconduct proceedings over alleged workplace bullying.

In a Philadelphia court case, three individuals were sentenced to prison for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive symbols. The attack, led by Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, was motivated by Campbell's belief that Valecce had harmed his cat, Pebbles, and stolen money and marijuana. The assault took place in the basement of Campbell's mother's house in Mayfair, lasting about 42 hours. Valecce suffered severe injuries, including broken ribs and wrists. During the attack, Valecce was tattooed with phrases and symbols, including "rip Pebbles" and offensive imagery. The perpetrators, described as "wannabe gangsters," filmed the abuse. Valecce managed to escape and contact police. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in prison, while his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, received 23 months. Carl Halin, 18, also received a 20-year sentence. David Harrison, 28, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed and reported ongoing trauma from the incident.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to acquire the 21-year-old Dutch international as one of his first signings. Van Gaal, familiar with Depay's abilities from the 2014 World Cup, where he named him in the squad, is interested in bringing him to the club. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helped PSV win the Dutch championship by defeating Heerenveen 4-1. Despite interest from Tottenham last summer and competition from clubs like Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United is in a strong position to sign him. Depay, born in 1994, began his career at VV Moordrecht and joined PSV at age 12, making his first-team debut in 2011. Known for his pace, dribbling, and shooting ability, he is compared to Arjen Robben and even Cristiano Ronaldo by scouts. Depay was part of the Netherlands' World Cup squad in 2014, scoring in matches against Australia and Chile.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team, taking a commanding lead back to West London. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, with Dominic Solanke adding a late goal to seal the win. Abraham's performance was notable, scoring his 35th and 36th goals of the season, though he was substituted due to injury. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalized in the first half, but Chelsea's defense, including Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, effectively neutralized City's threats. Key players for City included Kean Bryan, who was injured, and Brandon Barker, who created chances but couldn't capitalize. Chelsea's Ola Aina and Charlie Colkett were influential, with Colkett leading the midfield. The match highlighted Chelsea's strong attacking play and City's resilience despite their youth side's challenges.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, has stated that people are "born with a sexual preference" and believes that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He argues that state legislators, not courts, should decide on the legality of same-sex marriage, emphasizing that states have traditionally regulated marriage. Rubio has expressed that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, despite not agreeing with the decision, out of respect for their choice. He reiterated his belief that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Additionally, Rubio, a Catholic, believes divorce is wrong but would continue to love someone if they were divorced. He announced his presidential run and has reportedly secured significant financial commitments for the campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia, embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda, driven by their dream to explore the planet "a pedal at a time." After leaving their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they have been traveling as economically as possible, covering nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries in 356 days. They live on less than three euros per person per day, primarily by camping (161 nights out of 256) and using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their main expenses are food, costing about 2.74 euros per person per day. They started their journey in London, cycling through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They plan to continue into Asia, eventually aiming to cycle across the Pacific and the length of the American continent, expecting to be on the road for several more years. Their journey is documented on their blog, "The Crazy Travel."
